SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of exclamation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

[ ] All questionnaires
[ ] Pioneer health conditions
[ ] Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
[ ] Pioneer housing
[ ] Pioneer education and churchwork
[ ] Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

1. Your full name: George Arthur Hartwell

2. Your address: 209 Broad Street, Regina, Saskatchewan

3. Date: November 10, 1953

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   William J. C. Hartwell

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   July, 1882

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Toronto, Ontario.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question now.)
   I was in my teens, so I am assuming this is around 18 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Migrated to the West with my parents.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    By observation and living in the west.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

An older sister remained behind and thought we were foolish.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my family and a large number of other people.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Travelled by train to Brandon, Manitoba. It took a week to travel between Winnipeg and Brandon in an old coach at the rear of a trainload of settlers' effects. My father had charge of a car of ten oxen, which were used on red-river carts to make the trip overland to Saskatchewan.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.).

The death of a child of John Stillborn and the burial at Brandon.
A snow storm June 21st, at Virden - delaying us two days.
Getting stuck in the mud crossing the Saskatchewan Valley where our carts sunk down to the hubs - and which we were unable to move with even two and three yoke of oxen.
Squalling children, squealing cart wheels, singing humans, swearing men, bellowing oxen, laughing women, scolding women, quarrelling children, arguing men, barking dogs and, at the end of a day, setting up tents, building campfires, visiting other families and always evening prayers.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

On a homestead - in a tent which was later set up inside a log house that my father built and thatched with slough grass for the winter of 1882-1883 (the house was not completed).

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Two miles north of the present town of Lortie, on Section 12.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Left the homestead in 1886.
Lived east of the present site of Balcarres - 2 years.
Indian Head in 1888.
Then to Qu'Appelle (then known as Troy) 1890-1891.
1891-1908 in Kaukauna Wisconsin where I worked in paper mills until 1900 when I started railway work and returned to Prince Albert, Saskatchewan in 1908.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was 7½ years old when I came west with my parents. I worked on my Father's homestead and for Mr. Eatersby at 25 cents per day for one summer - and other farmers in the district. In 1888, I worked a summer for Major Bell on the then known Bell Farm at $8.00 a month - herding cattle and hogs and helping to milk 26 cows.

Began running a locomotive in 1908 and retired in Regina in the fall of 1940. On retirement moved to Lac Du Bonnet, Manitoba, and returned again to Regina in 1950.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

An older sister remained behind and thought we were foolish.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my family and a large number of other people.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Travelled by train to Brandon, Manitoba. It took a week to travel between Winnipeg and Brandon in an old coach at the rear of a trainload of settlers' effects. My father had charge of a car of ten oxen, which were used on red-river carts to make the trip overland to Saskatchewan.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.).

The death of a child of John Stillborn and the burial at Brandon.

A snow storm June 21st, at Virden - delaying us two days.

Getting stuck in the mud crossing the Saskatchewan Valley where our carts sunk down to the hubs - and which we were unable to move with even two and three yokes of oxen.

Small children, squealing cart wheels, sliding horses, swearing men, bellowing oxen, laughing women, squabbling children, quarrelling children, building campfires, visiting other families and always evening prayers.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

On a homestead - in a tent which was later set up inside a log house that my father built and thatched with slough grass for the winter of 1882-1883 (the house was not completed).

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Two miles north of the present town of Lorette, on Section 12.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Left the homestead in 1886.

Livestock east of the present site of Elmoor - 2 years.

Indian Head in 1888.

Then to Qu'Appelle (then known as Troop) 1890-1891.

Then to Kaukauna Wisconsin where I worked in paper mills until 1900.

1891-1908 in Kaukauna Wisconsin where I worked in paper mills until 1900.

When I started railway work and returned to Prince Albert, Saskatchewan in 1908.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was 74 years old when I came west with my parents. I worked on my father's homestead and for Mr. Hattersley at 25 cents per day for one summer - and other farmers in the district. In 1888, I worked a summer for Major Bell on the then known Bell Farm at $9.00 a month - herding cattle and hogs and helping to milk 26 cows.

Began running a locomotive in 1908 and retired in 1910. In the fall of 1910, on retirement moved to Lac Du Bonnet, Manitoba, and returned again to Regina in 1920.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Seldom

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date
    and place of marriage.
   In 1896 married Josephine Pravitz at Cogesh Wisconsin. She died in 1914.
   In 1918 married Emby Haavisto, at Winnipeg, Manitoba.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place
    to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West
    tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your
    memory which you would like to record?
   "In 1885 a band of Indians camped on our land. My father placed the family
    in the cart and took us to Pheasant Forks, where several other settlers
    congregated because of fear of an Indian uprising. After three weeks
    we returned and found everything complete—even the food we had left.

   Also remember getting lost in a March blizzard while having gone after wood
   with a John Allen (in 1886). We unhitched our teams, tied them up, and walked
   back and forth to keep warm all night, and when daylight came we found ourselves
   in his farm yard—only 150 yards from the house.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church,
    visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   In a radius of about two townships, 6 miles each way, every Sunday to
   Church at different homes, and odd week nights to debating clubs and
   spelling bees (by ox team)
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Seldom

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

In 1896 married Josephine Pravitz at Cogshall, Wisconsin. She died in 1914.

In 1910 married Ethel Harviston at Winnipeg, Manitoba.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

In 1895 a band of Indians camped on our land. My father placed the family in the cart and took us to Pleasant Forks, where several other settlers congregated because of fear of an Indian uprising. After three weeks we returned and found everything complete—even the food we had left.

Also remember getting lost in a March blizzard while having gone after wood with a John Allen (in 1886). We untied our teams, tied them up, and walked back and forth to keep warm all night, and when daylight came we found ourselves in his farm yard—only 150 yards from the house.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

In a radius of about two townships, 6 miles each way, every Sunday to church at different homes, and odd week nights to debating clubs and spelling bees (by ox team)
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   Not known

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   -------------

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Pheasant Forks about 8 miles, and about twice a year (spring and fall) made a trip to the railhead.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   About once every three weeks (in winter, by dog sled and snowshoes).

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Did not buy through the mail order catalogues.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   --

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Yes, when we came to Saskatchewan the first time it was with the idea of staying permanently.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   Not known.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What makes?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Pheasant Forks about 8 miles, and about twice a year (spring and fall) made a trip to the railhead.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new forms appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   About once every three weeks (in winter, by dog sled and snowshoes).

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the beginning of the period.

Did not buy through the mail order catalogues.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Yes, when we came to Saskatchewan the first time it was with the idea of staying permanently.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Not during 1882 to 1891 that I remember.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Active since 1900 in my trade union - Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers - I am still a member.

Active in the Independent Labor Party, since 1921, and active in the C.C.F. since its inception.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

---

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1); (2), (3).

"Primitive Methodist Colony" was the name given the district in which we lived and it was settled by a number of Methodist laymen and local preachers or circuit riders such as John Allen, John Todd, Samuel Teese (these three local preachers, as well as my father), J. B. Swift, John Webster, John Stillborn, William Stillborn, Quarter Stillborn, Frank Watts, Edward Hawkins, Ian Collins a Mr. Buckley, Frank Morely, (all with wife and families), also Joe Sedgwick, John Gamble, and Mary Hardy. All the above-named were in the same party that came over-land, I believe I am the only one left except a Mrs. Chipperfield - a daughter of John Stillborn, now living in Prince Albert - she being the twin sister of the child buried at Brandon on the trip over-land.
5.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1921? What reasons did they have for moving?
   Not during 1892 to 1991 that I remember.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible:
   - I am still a member.
   - Active in the Independent Labor Party, since 1921, and active in the C.C.P. since its inception.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were affiliated to have or do something in the district written in here, giving dates wherever possible, (such as owning the first automobile, containing organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, etc.)
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

No - except that I could recollect from memory several incidents and happenings connected with early settlement and people.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? (Indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Children: Mrs. Ruby Campbell, Saskatoon, Sask. - housewife
Mrs. Hazel Turner, Portland, Oregon, U.S.A. - cashier
Mrs. Anna Hallstead, Milwaukee, Wisconsin - nurse
Miss. Irma Hartwell, Regina, Sask. - Secretary
Mr. William A. Hartwell, Southern District Supervisor,
Department of Natural Resources, Regina.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

Methods of farming, modes of transportation, increased numbers of hamlets, villages, the growth of all cities (were none then), educational facilities, hospitals, churches, sport facilities, the loss of the wild prairie paradise, the severance of the old neighbourliness and get-together, the absence of water and old landmarks. The network of roads. The increase in population, and the increase of crime in proportion to the increase in population.
